title: 103_hr3820
content:
The Act may be cited as the "World War II Peace Accords Commemorative Coin Act". Congressional findings and sense of the Congress are included. The Congress finds that the 50th anniversary of the signing of the peace accords on September 2, 1995, should be recognized at the national level. It is suggested that the United States should mint and issue a commemorative coin to mark this occasion. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 500,000 half dollar coins commemorating the signing of the peace accords on September 2, 1945. The coins will have a specific design and be legal tender. Coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items for purposes of section 5132(a)(1) of title 31, United States Code. The design for the coins authorized by this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Admiral Nimitz Foundation and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued starting on January 1, 1995, in uncirculated and proof qualities, but minting will cease after December 31, 1995. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The Secretary will sell the coins at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing them. Bulk sales will be at a discount, and prepaid orders will also receive a reasonable discount. A surcharge of $5.00 per coin will be included in all sales.

SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to the Admiral Nimitz Foundation for preserving US Pacific War heritage. SEC. 9. AUDITS. SEC. 9. The Comptroller General can audit the Admiral Nimitz Foundation's expenditure under section 8. SEC. 10. Financial assurances. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
